title: How to Bake Herbed Potato Bread

steps.headline: Mash your potato.
steps.description: Boil water in a small saucepan. Once boiling, set the heat to medium-low, add your potato, cover the pan, and cook it for 15 to 20 minutes. Drain all but 1 cup (237 ml) of the liquid, mash the potato, then drizzle it with oil. Allow your potatoes and water to cool until they are lukewarm. The time this takes will vary, but in most cases it will take about 10 to 15 minutes.

steps.headline: Ready your work area.
steps.description: To make the most of your time, prepare your work area while your potato boils. To do so, lightly sprinkle flour on a clean work surface for kneading the dough later. Also coat the inside of a large bowl lightly with olive oil.

steps.headline: Mix ingredients in a large mixing bowl.
steps.description:
Stir sugar into 2 tbsp (30 ml) of lukewarm water in a large mixing bowl until it dissolves. Add the yeast, and continue to stir this until the mixture is foamy (about 5 minutes). Then:
Add your mashed potatoes and the 1 cup (237 ml) of water you saved when making the mashed potatoes. Beat whole wheat flour into the mixture for about a minute. Add rosemary, thyme, sage, and salt and stir until well distributed. Beat enough all-purpose flour into the mixture until it is too stiff to beat.

steps.headline: Knead the dough.
steps.description: Remove the dough from the bowl and place it on your clean, lightly floured work surface. Knead the dough until it is smooth and has an elastic quality. Do this for about 10 minutes. Add flour little by little to your surface, your kitchen tools, or to the dough ball itself when kneading to prevent it from sticking. For the quickest results and to save yourself some effort, you can use a stand-up mixer with a dough hook to prepare the dough.

steps.headline: Allow the dough to rise.
steps.description: Transfer your dough from the work surface to the lightly oiled bowl you prepared earlier. Turn the dough to completely coat it in the oil. Then use a thin layer of plastic wrap to close off the top of the bowl. After closing the top of the bowl, you'll have to wait 1½ hours for the dough to rise. When the dough has risen, it will be about double its starting size. Slightly before your dough has finished rising, coat a large baking sheet with cooking spray and sprinkle it with cornmeal.

steps.headline: Knead and separate the dough into halves.
steps.description: When the dough is done rising, transfer it again to your lightly floured work surface and punch it down. Knead the dough several times, then divide it into two halves and fashion each half into a ball. You may need to sprinkle more flour on your work surface before transferring the dough to it to prevent sticking.

steps.headline: Transfer your dough to your prepared baking sheet.
steps.description: Place the halves several inches apart on the sprayed, cornmeal sprinkled baking sheet. Cover the baking sheet and the halves on it completely with plastic wrap. Allow the dough to rise for one more hour. Half an hour before the dough finishes rising, put your baking stone or an inverted baking sheet on the middle rack of your oven. On the row beneath this, add a small baking pan. Preheat the oven to 450°F (232°C).

steps.headline: Bake the bread.
steps.description:
Add 1 cup (237 ml) of water to the baking pan on the lower rack of your oven. Take your baking sheet with the dough on it and place it on the baking stone or inverted baking sheet in the oven. Then:
Allow the loaves to bake for 20 minutes. Then decrease the temperature to 400°F (204°C).

steps.headline: Remove the bread from the oven and enjoy.
steps.description: Continue baking the dough for another 10 to 15 minutes after decreasing the oven temperature. When finished, the bread will look golden brown. The bottoms should sound hollow if you tap them. Cool the bread on a wire rack. When the bread is cool or slightly warm to the touch, it is ready to be eaten.

steps.headline: Preheat your oven.
steps.description: Especially if your oven takes a while to heat up, you'll want to begin preheating just before you start preparing this recipe. Set your oven to 375°F (190°C). Generally, you can expect preheating to take between 10 and 15 minutes.

steps.headline: Insert the diced potatoes and onions into your mixing bowl.
steps.description: Add your diced potatoes and onions to your mixing boil and drizzle these with olive oil. Then add your thyme and rosemary. Lightly season the ingredients with salt and pepper. Mix the contents of the bowl well. Mix these ingredients until the contents are well distributed and coated in the oil.

steps.headline: Layer your ingredients on a baking sheet.
steps.description: Layer your baking sheet with parchment paper. Use a spatula, spoon, or other suitable kitchen implement to push the ingredients from the mixing bowl onto the baking sheet in an even layer.

steps.headline: Bake your ingredients.
steps.description: Insert your ingredients into the oven. Bake these for about 20 minutes, or until the ingredients start to brown. When golden brown, remove the baking sheet from the oven and set it off to the side to cool. Items fresh from the oven will be very hot. Be sure to use safety implements, like potholders and oven mitts, to prevent burns or heat damage. To speed the cooling process, if you have enough room in your refrigerator, you may want to put the baking sheet there. Remember to put potholders under the sheet to prevent it from damaging your fridge shelving.

steps.headline: Ready your dough.
steps.description: Add your flour to a large mixing bowl. Use your clean hands or a kitchen implement to create a well in the flour. To the well, add the warm water, yeast, and sugar. Stir this together thoroughly until it begins to stick together to form dough.

steps.headline: Add your baked ingredients to the dough.
steps.description: If your baked ingredients have not yet cooled, wait until they do. Then add these to the dough along with the Parmesan and Gruyere cheese.

steps.headline: Mix all the ingredients together.
steps.description: A kitchen tool may work well for mixing, but the easiest way to ensure everything is well mixed is by working the dough with your hands. Form the dough into a ball. Always wash your hands before handling food directly when preparing it. This helps prevent the spread of bacteria and contamination.

steps.headline: Add the dough to your bread pan.
steps.description:
Line your bread pan with parchment paper to prevent the bread from sticking to the bottom of the pan. Use clean hands to press the dough down into the pan so that it completely covers the bottom of the pan. Then:
Allow the dough to rest, uncovered, in a warm place for 10 to 15 minutes. To prepare for baking, lower your oven temperature to 355°F (180°C).

steps.headline: Bake your dough.
steps.description: Brush the top of the dough lightly with olive oil until it is completely covered. Insert your pan and the dough into the oven and allow this to bake for 40 minutes. Then remove the bread pan from the oven using potholders or an oven mitt.

steps.headline: Allow the bread to cool and then enjoy.
steps.description: The bread should remain in the hot pan for 5 to 10 minutes after being removed from the oven. Then transfer the bread from the bread pan to a wire rack. Allow the bread to cool. When the bread has cooled, it's ready to eat.

methods.name: Preparing Gluten Free Herbed Potato Bread

steps.headline: Sift your flour and combine it with the dry ingredients.
steps.description: Sift your flour (both tapioca flour and almond flour) into a large mixing bowl. Add the salt, garlic, and dried herbs to this. Mix these until well distributed.

steps.headline: Combine your wet ingredients with sugar and mix in the yeast.
steps.description: In a separate, clean mixing bowl, add your warm milk and coconut sugar. Stir these lightly until the sugar dissolves, then mix in your yeast. Set this off to the side for five minutes so the yeast will activate.

steps.headline: Add an egg, vinegar, and oil mixture to the yeast mixture.
steps.description: In a small, clean mixing bowl, whisk the egg and egg white together. To this, add the vinegar and olive oil. Continue whisking for a few minutes, then pour the mixture in with the yeast and milk.

steps.headline: Combine the wet and dry ingredients.
steps.description: Mix in your dry ingredients (the flours, salt, garlic, and dried herbs) to the wet ingredients. Quickly mix all these together by beating the mixture thoroughly.

steps.headline: Insert the mashed potatoes and onions to the mix.
steps.description: Add your mashed potatoes to the combined wet and dry ingredients. Mix this until it is smooth and begins to clump like dough. The mix should be relatively firm at this point and difficult to stir/work. Fold in your onions.

steps.headline: Let the dough rise.
steps.description: The dough should remain in its bowl while rising. Cover the bowl with a warm cloth. Set the dough aside for about 60 to 70 minutes until it rises. This may take longer if you did not use quick rise yeast. While your bread is rising, this is an excellent opportunity to set your oven to 350°F (177°C).

steps.headline: Bake your bread.
steps.description: Line the bottom of your bread pan with parchment paper. Transfer the bread from the bowl to the lined bread pan. Bake the dough for about 45 to 50 minutes or until the top turns golden brown. Remove the pan from the oven with potholders or an oven mitt, then set the pan somewhere to cool completely. When it cools, it's ready to eat. Before you put your bread into the oven, you may want to top the dough with some extra herbs and chopped onion. You can also sprinkle grated Parmesan on top.

steps.headline: Finished.

tyn: Potato masher (or a sturdy fork, etc.)
Mixing bowl (large size, x2; small size, x1)
text:

Drain all but 1 cup (237 ml) of the liquid, mash the potato, then drizzle it with oil. Allow your potatoes and water to cool until they are lukewarm. The time this takes will vary, but in most cases it will take about 10 to 15 minutes. Ready your work area. To make the most of your time, prepare your work area while your potato boils. To do so, lightly sprinkle flour on a clean work surface for kneading the dough later. Also coat the inside of a large bowl lightly with olive oil. Mix ingredients in a large mixing bowl. Stir sugar into 2 tbsp (30 ml) of lukewarm water in a large mixing bowl until it dissolves. Add the yeast, and continue to stir this until the mixture is foamy (about 5 minutes). Then:
Add your mashed potatoes and the 1 cup (237 ml) of water you saved when making the mashed potatoes. Beat whole wheat flour into the mixture for about a minute. Add rosemary, thyme, sage, and salt and stir until well distributed. Beat enough all-purpose flour into the mixture until it is too stiff to beat. Knead the dough. Remove the dough from the bowl and place it on your clean, lightly floured work surface. Knead the dough until it is smooth and has an elastic quality. Do this for about 10 minutes. Add flour little by little to your surface, your kitchen tools, or to the dough ball itself when kneading to prevent it from sticking. For the quickest results and to save yourself some effort, you can use a stand-up mixer with a dough hook to prepare the dough. Allow the dough to rise. Transfer your dough from the work surface to the lightly oiled bowl you prepared earlier. Turn the dough to completely coat it in the oil. Then use a thin layer of plastic wrap to close off the top of the bowl. After closing the top of the bowl, you'll have to wait 1½ hours for the dough to rise. When the dough has risen, it will be about double its starting size. Slightly before your dough has finished rising, coat a large baking sheet with cooking spray and sprinkle it with cornmeal. Knead and separate the dough into halves. When the dough is done rising, transfer it again to your lightly floured work surface and punch it down. Knead the dough several times, then divide it into two halves and fashion each half into a ball. You may need to sprinkle more flour on your work surface before transferring the dough to it to prevent sticking. Transfer your dough to your prepared baking sheet. Place the halves several inches apart on the sprayed, cornmeal sprinkled baking sheet. Cover the baking sheet and the halves on it completely with plastic wrap. Allow the dough to rise for one more hour. Half an hour before the dough finishes rising, put your baking stone or an inverted baking sheet on the middle rack of your oven. On the row beneath this, add a small baking pan. Preheat the oven to 450°F (232°C). Bake the bread. Add 1 cup (237 ml) of water to the baking pan on the lower rack of your oven. Take your baking sheet with the dough on it and place it on the baking stone or inverted baking sheet in the oven. Then:
Allow the loaves to bake for 20 minutes. Then decrease the temperature to 400°F (204°C). Remove the bread from the oven and enjoy. Continue baking the dough for another 10 to 15 minutes after decreasing the oven temperature. When finished, the bread will look golden brown. The bottoms should sound hollow if you tap them. Cool the bread on a wire rack. When the bread is cool or slightly warm to the touch, it is ready to be eaten. Creating Cheesy Herbed Potato Bread Preheat your oven. Especially if your oven takes a while to heat up, you'll want to begin preheating just before you start preparing this recipe. Set your oven to 375°F (190°C). Generally, you can expect preheating to take between 10 and 15 minutes. Insert the diced potatoes and onions into your mixing bowl. Add your diced potatoes and onions to your mixing boil and drizzle these with olive oil. Then add your thyme and rosemary. Lightly season the ingredients with salt and pepper. Mix the contents of the bowl well. Mix these ingredients until the contents are well distributed and coated in the oil. Layer your ingredients on a baking sheet. Layer your baking sheet with parchment paper. Use a spatula, spoon, or other suitable kitchen implement to push the ingredients from the mixing bowl onto the baking sheet in an even layer. Bake your ingredients. Insert your ingredients into the oven. Bake these for about 20 minutes, or until the ingredients start to brown. When golden brown, remove the baking sheet from the oven and set it off to the side to cool. Items fresh from the oven will be very hot. Be sure to use safety implements, like potholders and oven mitts, to prevent burns or heat damage. To speed the cooling process, if you have enough room in your refrigerator, you may want to put the baking sheet there. Remember to put potholders under the sheet to prevent it from damaging your fridge shelving. Ready your dough. Add your flour to a large mixing bowl. Use your clean hands or a kitchen implement to create a well in the flour. To the well, add the warm water, yeast, and sugar. Stir this together thoroughly until it begins to stick together to form dough. Add your baked ingredients to the dough. If your baked ingredients have not yet cooled, wait until they do. Then add these to the dough along with the Parmesan and Gruyere cheese. Mix all the ingredients together. A kitchen tool may work well for mixing, but the easiest way to ensure everything is well mixed is by working the dough with your hands. Form the dough into a ball. Always wash your hands before handling food directly when preparing it. This helps prevent the spread of bacteria and contamination. Add the dough to your bread pan. Line your bread pan with parchment paper to prevent the bread from sticking to the bottom of the pan. Use clean hands to press the dough down into the pan so that it completely covers the bottom of the pan. Then:
Allow the dough to rest, uncovered, in a warm place for 10 to 15 minutes. To prepare for baking, lower your oven temperature to 355°F (180°C). Bake your dough. Brush the top of the dough lightly with olive oil until it is completely covered. Insert your pan and the dough into the oven and allow this to bake for 40 minutes. Then remove the bread pan from the oven using potholders or an oven mitt. Allow the bread to cool and then enjoy. The bread should remain in the hot pan for 5 to 10 minutes after being removed from the oven. Then transfer the bread from the bread pan to a wire rack. Allow the bread to cool. When the bread has cooled, it's ready to eat. Preparing Gluten Free Herbed Potato Bread Sift your flour and combine it with the dry ingredients. Sift your flour (both tapioca flour and almond flour) into a large mixing bowl. Add the salt, garlic, and dried herbs to this. Mix these until well distributed. Combine your wet ingredients with sugar and mix in the yeast. In a separate, clean mixing bowl, add your warm milk and coconut sugar. Stir these lightly until the sugar dissolves, then mix in your yeast. Set this off to the side for five minutes so the yeast will activate. Add an egg, vinegar, and oil mixture to the yeast mixture. In a small, clean mixing bowl, whisk the egg and egg white together. To this, add the vinegar and olive oil. Continue whisking for a few minutes, then pour the mixture in with the yeast and milk. Combine the wet and dry ingredients. Mix in your dry ingredients (the flours, salt, garlic, and dried herbs) to the wet ingredients. Quickly mix all these together by beating the mixture thoroughly. Insert the mashed potatoes and onions to the mix. Add your mashed potatoes to the combined wet and dry ingredients. Mix this until it is smooth and begins to clump like dough. The mix should be relatively firm at this point and difficult to stir/work. Fold in your onions. Let the dough rise. The dough should remain in its bowl while rising. Remove the pan from the oven with potholders or an oven mitt, then set the pan somewhere to cool completely. When it cools, it's ready to eat. Before you put your bread into the oven, you may want to top the dough with some extra herbs and chopped onion. You can also sprinkle grated Parmesan on top. Finished.
sentences: Making Herbed Potato Bread Mash your potato.
Boil water in a small saucepan.
Once boiling, set the heat to medium-low, add your potato, cover the pan, and cook it for 15 to 20 minutes.
Drain all but 1 cup (237 ml) of the liquid, mash the potato, then drizzle it with oil.
Allow your potatoes and water to cool until they are lukewarm.
The time this takes will vary, but in most cases it will take about 10 to 15 minutes.
Ready your work area.
To make the most of your time, prepare your work area while your potato boils.
To do so, lightly sprinkle flour on a clean work surface for kneading the dough later.
Also coat the inside of a large bowl lightly with olive oil.
Mix ingredients in a large mixing bowl.
Stir sugar into 2 tbsp (30 ml) of lukewarm water in a large mixing bowl until it dissolves.
Add the yeast, and continue to stir this until the mixture is foamy (about 5 minutes).

Then:
Add your mashed potatoes and the 1 cup (237 ml) of water you saved when making the mashed potatoes.
Beat whole wheat flour into the mixture for about a minute.
Add rosemary, thyme, sage, and salt and stir until well distributed.
Beat enough all-purpose flour into the mixture until it is too stiff to beat.
Knead the dough.
Remove the dough from the bowl and place it on your clean, lightly floured work surface.
Knead the dough until it is smooth and has an elastic quality.
Do this for about 10 minutes.
Add flour little by little to your surface, your kitchen tools, or to the dough ball itself when kneading to prevent it from sticking.
For the quickest results and to save yourself some effort, you can use a stand-up mixer with a dough hook to prepare the dough.
Allow the dough to rise.
Transfer your dough from the work surface to the lightly oiled bowl you prepared earlier.
Turn the dough to completely coat it in the oil.
Then use a thin layer of plastic wrap to close off the top of the bowl.
After closing the top of the bowl, you'll have to wait 1½ hours for the dough to rise.
When the dough has risen, it will be about double its starting size.
Slightly before your dough has finished rising, coat a large baking sheet with cooking spray and sprinkle it with cornmeal.
Knead and separate the dough into halves.
When the dough is done rising, transfer it again to your lightly floured work surface and punch it down.
Knead the dough several times, then divide it into two halves and fashion each half into a ball.
You may need to sprinkle more flour on your work surface before transferring the dough to it to prevent sticking.
Transfer your dough to your prepared baking sheet.
Place the halves several inches apart on the sprayed, cornmeal sprinkled baking sheet.
Cover the baking sheet and the halves on it completely with plastic wrap.
Allow the dough to rise for one more hour.
Half an hour before the dough finishes rising, put your baking stone or an inverted baking sheet on the middle rack of your oven.
On the row beneath this, add a small baking pan.
Preheat the oven to 450°F (232°C).
Bake the bread.
Add 1 cup (237 ml) of water to the baking pan on the lower rack of your oven.
Take your baking sheet with the dough on it and place it on the baking stone or inverted baking sheet in the oven.

Then:
Allow the loaves to bake for 20 minutes.
Then decrease the temperature to 400°F (204°C).
Remove the bread from the oven and enjoy.
Continue baking the dough for another 10 to 15 minutes after decreasing the oven temperature.
When finished, the bread will look golden brown.
The bottoms should sound hollow if you tap them.
Cool the bread on a wire rack.
When the bread is cool or slightly warm to the touch, it is ready to be eaten.

Set your oven to 375°F (190°C).

Add the salt, garlic, and dried herbs to this.
Mix these until well distributed.
Combine your wet ingredients with sugar and mix in the yeast.
In a separate, clean mixing bowl, add your warm milk and coconut sugar.
Stir these lightly until the sugar dissolves, then mix in your yeast.
Set this off to the side for five minutes so the yeast will activate.
Add an egg, vinegar, and oil mixture to the yeast mixture.
In a small, clean mixing bowl, whisk the egg and egg white together.
To this, add the vinegar and olive oil.
Continue whisking for a few minutes, then pour the mixture in with the yeast and milk.
Combine the wet and dry ingredients.
Mix in your dry ingredients (the flours, salt, garlic, and dried herbs) to the wet ingredients.
Quickly mix all these together by beating the mixture thoroughly.
Insert the mashed potatoes and onions to the mix.
Add your mashed potatoes to the combined wet and dry ingredients.
Mix this until it is smooth and begins to clump like dough.
The mix should be relatively firm at this point and difficult to stir/work.
Fold in your onions.
Let the dough rise.
The dough should remain in its bowl while rising.
Cover the bowl with a warm cloth.
Set the dough aside for about 60 to 70 minutes until it rises.
This may take longer if you did not use quick rise yeast.
While your bread is rising, this is an excellent opportunity to set your oven to 350°F (177°C).
Bake your bread.
Line the bottom of your bread pan with parchment paper.
Transfer the bread from the bowl to the lined bread pan.
Bake the dough for about 45 to 50 minutes or until the top turns golden brown.
Remove the pan from the oven with potholders or an oven mitt, then set the pan somewhere to cool completely.
When it cools, it's ready to eat.
Before you put your bread into the oven, you may want to top the dough with some extra herbs and chopped onion.
You can also sprinkle grated Parmesan on top.
Finished.
